Award.AwardTitle: Nebraska-Rouen Collaborations: Hyperbranched Polar Polymers as Solid Lubricants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will address a very fundamental component in materials processing and manufacturing: grafting polar polymers to surfaces of a solid nanomaterial to create metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). This project will bring together three research groups with highly specialized expertise in an interdisciplinary approach to investigate surface corrosion, defect repair, and polymer binding on MOFs, as well as examine the kinetics of the grafting process. The goal is to develop solid lubricants which are essential in manufacturing processes and in applications of materials in highly demanding environments, such as long-term biomedical implants. This approach, which has never been attempted, would be a significant contribution to the field of materials research into solid lubricants.

Research into new processes to develop new properties of materials is critical to creating uses for materials in applications as varied as biomedical devices and automotive manufacturing. Solid lubricants would be invaluable applications in automotive manufacture where there are stringent standards for wear protection. The collaboration will also introduce US students and postdocs at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln to the facilities and expertise available at the Universite de Rouen and provide valuable training to enable the US to develop a globally competitive science workforce.

Institution.Name: University of Nebraska-Lincoln
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soft and flexible materials have had huge growth or development in the current era of smart & portable electronics.  Softness of the material, easiness in processing and manufacturing, and enriched functionalities from microelectronic units all have promoted their vast growth and popularity throughout all ages of customers.  Instead of focusing on the material issues along the human-computer interfaces, this current project focused on polymer nanocomposites to harness the bulk properties of polymer matrix and, at the same time, to take advantage of the unique properties from nanomaterials.  Two different approaches are adopted, one by grafting polymers on state-of-the art metal oxide framework (MOFs) surfaces and the other by growing nanoparticles of metals directly inside a soft polymer matrix.  As MOFs show orientation-dependent surface functional groups, we can individually decorate each crystal surface with different type of protein molecules.  Beyond the surface grafting with large molecules, patching small molecules render MOFs unusual healing capability at -56 degree C.  In the direction of planting metal nanoparticles in soft polymer matrix, as the soft matrix houses immense amount of ions, deformable network structure of metal nanoparticles can accomodate these ions to show unprecedented change in capacitance to external static or dynamic load (touch, airflow, and underwater acoustic wave).


Last Modified: 12/31/2015
Modified by: Li Tan

  • MOFs carry distinct surface functional groups that can be patched at a very low temperature of -56 degree C.
    Ziguang Chen, Li Tan

    Metal-Organic Frameworks Self-healing at Low Temperatures
  • Metal nano particles of silver are planted inside the shallow surface of hydrogels.
    Yang Gao, Christian Elowsky, You Zhou, Li Tan
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Li Tan
    Network of Metal Nanoparticles in Hydrogels
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Soft and flexible materials have had huge growth or development in the current era of smart & portable electronics. Softness of the material, easiness in processing and manufacturing, and enriched functionalities from microelectronic units all have promoted their vast growth and popularity throughout all ages of customers. Instead of focusing on the material issues along the human-computer interfaces, this current project focused on polymer nanocomposites to harness the bulk properties of polymer matrix and, at the same time, to take advantage of the unique properties from nanomaterials. Two different approaches are adopted, one by grafting polymers on state-of-the art metal oxide framework (MOFs) surfaces and the other by growing nanoparticles of metals directly inside a soft polymer matrix. As MOFs show orientation-dependent surface functional groups, we can individually decorate each crystal surface with different type of protein molecules. Beyond the surface grafting with large molecules, patching small molecules render MOFs unusual healing capability at -56 degree C. In the direction of planting metal nanoparticles in soft polymer matrix, as the soft matrix houses immense amount of ions, deformable network structure of metal nanoparticles can accomodate these ions to show unprecedented change in capacitance to external static or dynamic load (touch, airflow, and underwater acoustic wave).
